values.description:
~~Depends on pull request #200 and pull request #201. Please review them first~~

Adds ogre1.x and ogre2.x implementation of a thermal camera.

The data output is an image of single channel 16 bit temperature values. Typical thermal sensors produces data in 10mK or 100mK resolutions and this behavior can be configured by setting the thermal camera’s LinearResolution.

e.g. for LinearResolution of 0.01 \(10mK\), the max temperature data generated is:

65535 \* 0.01 = 655.35 Kelvin / 680.72 F / 360.4 C

Another example is the FLIR Lepton camera which outputs 14 bit data, which can be simulated by setting LinearResolution to 0.04.

The temperature of a Visual can be set using `Visual::SetUserData` function introduced in pull request #200 with the key `temperature`, and the environment temperature is set using `TheramlCamera::SetAmbientTemperature`

‌

Update [70b4a9b](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/commits/70b4a9b65a06fed9e64e2a7bffcc360192a31897): Added function to set temperature variation for heat sources \(instead of using a hard coded value\).  If not set, uniform temperature is assumed for the entire body of the heat source.
values.title: Add ThermalCamera

summary.raw:
~~Depends on pull request #200 and pull request #201. Please review them first~~

Adds ogre1.x and ogre2.x implementation of a thermal camera.

The data output is an image of single channel 16 bit temperature values. Typical thermal sensors produces data in 10mK or 100mK resolutions and this behavior can be configured by setting the thermal camera’s LinearResolution.

e.g. for LinearResolution of 0.01 \(10mK\), the max temperature data generated is:

65535 \* 0.01 = 655.35 Kelvin / 680.72 F / 360.4 C

Another example is the FLIR Lepton camera which outputs 14 bit data, which can be simulated by setting LinearResolution to 0.04.

The temperature of a Visual can be set using `Visual::SetUserData` function introduced in pull request #200 with the key `temperature`, and the environment temperature is set using `TheramlCamera::SetAmbientTemperature`

‌

Update [70b4a9b](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/commits/70b4a9b65a06fed9e64e2a7bffcc360192a31897): Added function to set temperature variation for heat sources \(instead of using a hard coded value\).  If not set, uniform temperature is assumed for the entire body of the heat source.
summary.html:
Depends on pull request #200 and pull request #201. Please review them first

Adds ogre1.x and ogre2.x implementation of a thermal camera.

The data output is an image of single channel 16 bit temperature values. Typical thermal sensors produces data in 10mK or 100mK resolutions and this behavior can be configured by setting the thermal camera’s LinearResolution.

e.g. for LinearResolution of 0.01 (10mK), the max temperature data generated is:

65535 * 0.01 = 655.35 Kelvin / 680.72 F / 360.4 C

Another example is the FLIR Lepton camera which outputs 14 bit data, which can be simulated by setting LinearResolution to 0.04.

The temperature of a Visual can be set using Visual::SetUserData function introduced in pull request #200 with the key temperature, and the environment temperature is set using TheramlCamera::SetAmbientTemperature

‌

Update 70b4a9b: Added function to set temperature variation for heat sources (instead of using a hard coded value). If not set, uniform temperature is assumed for the entire body of the heat source.

values.description:
issue #53

See [diff without whitespaces](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/pull-requests/203/ogre2-add-more-shadow-maps/diff?w=1) which is easier to review

in the current ogre2 implementation, only the 2 closest spot/point lights can cast shadows. That’s mainly because only two shadow maps are reserved for spot/point lights in the ogre compositor script \(shadow\_map 3 and 4\). This PR increase the number to 16 \(shadow\_map 3 to 18\)

Updated `ogre2_demo` to test spot light shadows. There are now 12 shadow casting lights in the scene: 1 directional light, 1 point light, 10 spotlights \(9 of which are the ones above the green boxes added in this PR\)

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/zq9ear/images/215182083-ogre2_shadows.png)
‌

‌

‌

‌
values.title: Ogre2: Add more shadow maps

values.description:
* The parameter of `Ogre::SimpleRenderable::setMaterial` changed from String to Material in 1.10.8. So the call is now wrapped with `ifdef` ogre version check.
* There were unresolved symbols for `Marker` class. Adding empty constructor and destructor in cpp file fixed the problem. We did something similar for [GaussianNoisePass](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/src/default/src/GaussianNoisePass.cc) class to get rid of these errors. It’s still a mystery to me as to why other classes do not have this problem

[windows build](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ign_rendering-pr-win/455/) - fixed
values.title: Fix windows build

summary.raw:
* The parameter of `Ogre::SimpleRenderable::setMaterial` changed from String to Material in 1.10.8. So the call is now wrapped with `ifdef` ogre version check.
* There were unresolved symbols for `Marker` class. Adding empty constructor and destructor in cpp file fixed the problem. We did something similar for [GaussianNoisePass](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/src/default/src/GaussianNoisePass.cc) class to get rid of these errors. It’s still a mystery to me as to why other classes do not have this problem

[windows build](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ign_rendering-pr-win/455/) - fixed
summary.html:
• The parameter of Ogre::SimpleRenderable::setMaterial changed from String to Material in 1.10.8. So the call is now wrapped with ifdef ogre version check.
  • There were unresolved symbols for Marker class. Adding empty constructor and destructor in cpp file fixed the problem. We did something similar for GaussianNoisePass class to get rid of these errors. It’s still a mystery to me as to why other classes do not have this problem

windows build - fixed

values.description:
Added Ogre2Marker class. Currently only supports simple primitive geometries \(boxes, cylinders, spheres\). Dynamic renderables like points and lines are not working yet.

The `Ogre2Dynamic*` classes were removed as I found that the ogre base class, SimpleRenderable, which we derive from may not work anymore in ogre2. It’s better not to include these classes in the next release if they don’t work. The proper way to create dynamic renderables in ogre2 may involve using vertex array objects \(VAO\), [ogre2 sample here](https://github.com/OGRECave/ogre-next/tree/v2-1/Samples/2.0/ApiUsage/CustomRenderable).

‌
values.title: Add Ogre2 Markers

summary.raw:
Added Ogre2Marker class. Currently only supports simple primitive geometries \(boxes, cylinders, spheres\). Dynamic renderables like points and lines are not working yet.

The `Ogre2Dynamic*` classes were removed as I found that the ogre base class, SimpleRenderable, which we derive from may not work anymore in ogre2. It’s better not to include these classes in the next release if they don’t work. The proper way to create dynamic renderables in ogre2 may involve using vertex array objects \(VAO\), [ogre2 sample here](https://github.com/OGRECave/ogre-next/tree/v2-1/Samples/2.0/ApiUsage/CustomRenderable).

‌
summary.html:
Added Ogre2Marker class. Currently only supports simple primitive geometries (boxes, cylinders, spheres). Dynamic renderables like points and lines are not working yet.

The Ogre2Dynamic* classes were removed as I found that the ogre base class, SimpleRenderable, which we derive from may not work anymore in ogre2. It’s better not to include these classes in the next release if they don’t work. The proper way to create dynamic renderables in ogre2 may involve using vertex array objects (VAO), ogre2 sample here.

values.description:
A similar [change](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/pull-requests/208/add-ogre2-markers/diff#Logre/src/OgreVisual.ccT97) was applied to ogre1 as part of pull request #208 but left out for ogre2

This change also fixes ogre2’s `UNIT_Visual_TEST`, which can be run as follows:

```
RENDER_ENGINE_VALUES=ogre2 ./build/ignition-rendering3/bin/UNIT_Visual_TEST
```

‌

values.description:
Fix an issue with lights not casting shadows when there are more lights \(shadow-casting \+ non-shadow-casting\) in the scene than the number of shadow maps specified in the compositor.

Apparently, just by having a shadow-casting directional light in the scene, shadows for other lights start working again. So the workaround to always create a directional light but initially set it as disabled, and later re-enabled it when user requests a directional light.

Here’s a screenshot showing the spot lights are now properly occluded and no longer leaks through the wall.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/zq9ear/images/3787883042-spot_light_shadows.png)
‌
values.title: Ogre2: Fix spot light shadows

summary.raw:
Fix an issue with lights not casting shadows when there are more lights \(shadow-casting \+ non-shadow-casting\) in the scene than the number of shadow maps specified in the compositor.

Apparently, just by having a shadow-casting directional light in the scene, shadows for other lights start working again. So the workaround to always create a directional light but initially set it as disabled, and later re-enabled it when user requests a directional light.

Here’s a screenshot showing the spot lights are now properly occluded and no longer leaks through the wall.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/zq9ear/images/3787883042-spot_light_shadows.png)
‌
summary.html:
Fix an issue with lights not casting shadows when there are more lights (shadow-casting + non-shadow-casting) in the scene than the number of shadow maps specified in the compositor.

Apparently, just by having a shadow-casting directional light in the scene, shadows for other lights start working again. So the workaround to always create a directional light but initially set it as disabled, and later re-enabled it when user requests a directional light.

Here’s a screenshot showing the spot lights are now properly occluded and no longer leaks through the wall.

‌

values.description:
Replaces pull request #217. Third attempt - Shadows should hopefully work properly now!

The main cause of a problem was that the shadow casting lights did not match the ones statically defined in `PbsMaterials.compositor`. The original PR tries to workaround the issue but I ran into a bug in ogre2 that prevents it from working in some cases.

To fix the problem, I now programmatically construct the shadow node whenever the number of shadow casting lights changes so that we always use the correct number of shadow maps. 

I ran into a different bug in ogre2 for dynamically creating the shadow nodes. I had to adapt its code and fix the bug in `Ogre2RenderTarget::CreateShadowNodeWithSettings` function.

Screenshot from tunnel.sdf that uses version 3 of X1 UGV model from fuel

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/zq9ear/images/445905331-spot_light_shadows_tunnel.png)
‌

‌
values.title: Ogre2: Fix shadows by dynamically generating shadow maps

The main cause of a problem was that the shadow casting lights did not match the ones statically defined in `PbsMaterials.compositor`. The original PR tries to workaround the issue but I ran into a bug in ogre2 that prevents it from working in some cases.

To fix the problem, I now programmatically construct the shadow node whenever the number of shadow casting lights changes so that we always use the correct number of shadow maps. 

I ran into a different bug in ogre2 for dynamically creating the shadow nodes. I had to adapt its code and fix the bug in `Ogre2RenderTarget::CreateShadowNodeWithSettings` function.

summary.html:
Replaces pull request #217. Third attempt - Shadows should hopefully work properly now!

The main cause of a problem was that the shadow casting lights did not match the ones statically defined in PbsMaterials.compositor. The original PR tries to workaround the issue but I ran into a bug in ogre2 that prevents it from working in some cases.

To fix the problem, I now programmatically construct the shadow node whenever the number of shadow casting lights changes so that we always use the correct number of shadow maps.

I ran into a different bug in ogre2 for dynamically creating the shadow nodes. I had to adapt its code and fix the bug in Ogre2RenderTarget::CreateShadowNodeWithSettings function.

Screenshot from tunnel.sdf that uses version 3 of X1 UGV model from fuel

‌

‌

values.description: When testing in subt with 14\+ shadow-casting lights, I ran into a situation in which ogre2 sometimes goes into a infinite loop while cleaning up old shadow node resources.  This PR makes explicit call to destroy all resources before rebuilding the compositor \(and the shadow node\) and that fixed the problem.
values.title: Ogre2: Destroy resources before recreating shadows

summary.raw: When testing in subt with 14\+ shadow-casting lights, I ran into a situation in which ogre2 sometimes goes into a infinite loop while cleaning up old shadow node resources.  This PR makes explicit call to destroy all resources before rebuilding the compositor \(and the shadow node\) and that fixed the problem.
summary.html: When testing in subt with 14+ shadow-casting lights, I ran into a situation in which ogre2 sometimes goes into a infinite loop while cleaning up old shadow node resources. This PR makes explicit call to destroy all resources before rebuilding the compositor (and the shadow node) and that fixed the problem.

values.description:
Note, this is pretty much a work in progress and I’m not too familiar with ogre so I might have missed something or introduced regressions, especially in the ogre1 code.

This PR is to get collada assets with alpha textures to work properly in ignition, both with ogre1 and ogre2.

First of all the asset can be found [here](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1vKCbR9AxiEyjsJ5ISIRIcARl81jfTqzE/view?usp=sharing), it’s a slightly modified version of the one in [this issue](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issues/2640/alpha-textures-not-supported) \(added transparency \+ transparent properties to the cage object\).

Also, in order for this PR to have any effect it is necessary to remove the part of the ColladaLoader in ign-common that overwrites the transparency with a value of 0 and issues a warning whenever a <texture> property is found inside a <transparent> tag, related PR [here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/pull-requests/219/transparent-textures/diff).

I tested both the asset attached \(to verify the change\) and a non-textured asset with transparent materials from [fuel](https://app.ignitionrobotics.org/openrobotics/fuel/models/Cafe) to make sure there was no regressions. Both seem to render correctly but I might have missed something. Now the details.

### Ogre2

* Setting the blend type to transparent alpha makes the texture render correctly but shadows are wrong. The only way I could get the shadows to work correctly is by setting:

    * AlphaTest: With this setting the shadows that the object projects on the outside are correct \(instead of being solid\).
    * TwoSidedLighting: Setting this to true was the only way I could get the shadows inside the objects to be correct \(the grid projecting a shadow on the blue bag\), otherwise there is none.
    
* The alpha test threshold is an arbitrary number which changes the projected shadows slightly, I’m open to making it a parameter \(although this would probably mean breaking API\).

    * If we make the threshold a parameter, where should it come from?
    
* I’m open to how we should implement transparency for textures. For now the transparency parameter is still taken and applied to the whole texture \(hence even fully opaque alpha textures will be partially transparent, depending on the parameter value\). Is this a good behavior or would we want to only use the texture’s alpha channel? I’m afraid that since we need to specify a transparency value greater than 0 to enable alpha blending it will actually be impossible to have a completely opaque texture and this sounds wrong.

### OGRE1

* I removed the manual override of the alpha channel and that fixed the rendering of the cage but to be honest I didn’t spend much time on this so I might have introduced some regression, I’d like to know from who wrote that part in the first place in which cases it was needed.
* There is still no shadow being projected by the cage on the blue bag. I’ll be looking into fixing this in the coming days.

‌

Again this is very much a work in progress, and since we are adding a previously unimplemented functionality feedback on what the feature should look like from an end user point of view is welcome!

‌
values.title: Added basic support for alpha textures in ogre1 and ogre2

summary.raw:
Note, this is pretty much a work in progress and I’m not too familiar with ogre so I might have missed something or introduced regressions, especially in the ogre1 code.

This PR is to get collada assets with alpha textures to work properly in ignition, both with ogre1 and ogre2.

First of all the asset can be found [here](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1vKCbR9AxiEyjsJ5ISIRIcARl81jfTqzE/view?usp=sharing), it’s a slightly modified version of the one in [this issue](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issues/2640/alpha-textures-not-supported) \(added transparency \+ transparent properties to the cage object\).

Also, in order for this PR to have any effect it is necessary to remove the part of the ColladaLoader in ign-common that overwrites the transparency with a value of 0 and issues a warning whenever a <texture> property is found inside a <transparent> tag, related PR [here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/pull-requests/219/transparent-textures/diff).

I tested both the asset attached \(to verify the change\) and a non-textured asset with transparent materials from [fuel](https://app.ignitionrobotics.org/openrobotics/fuel/models/Cafe) to make sure there was no regressions. Both seem to render correctly but I might have missed something. Now the details.

### Ogre2

* Setting the blend type to transparent alpha makes the texture render correctly but shadows are wrong. The only way I could get the shadows to work correctly is by setting:

    * AlphaTest: With this setting the shadows that the object projects on the outside are correct \(instead of being solid\).
    * TwoSidedLighting: Setting this to true was the only way I could get the shadows inside the objects to be correct \(the grid projecting a shadow on the blue bag\), otherwise there is none.
    
* The alpha test threshold is an arbitrary number which changes the projected shadows slightly, I’m open to making it a parameter \(although this would probably mean breaking API\).

    * If we make the threshold a parameter, where should it come from?
    
* I’m open to how we should implement transparency for textures. For now the transparency parameter is still taken and applied to the whole texture \(hence even fully opaque alpha textures will be partially transparent, depending on the parameter value\). Is this a good behavior or would we want to only use the texture’s alpha channel? I’m afraid that since we need to specify a transparency value greater than 0 to enable alpha blending it will actually be impossible to have a completely opaque texture and this sounds wrong.

### OGRE1

* I removed the manual override of the alpha channel and that fixed the rendering of the cage but to be honest I didn’t spend much time on this so I might have introduced some regression, I’d like to know from who wrote that part in the first place in which cases it was needed.
* There is still no shadow being projected by the cage on the blue bag. I’ll be looking into fixing this in the coming days.

‌

Again this is very much a work in progress, and since we are adding a previously unimplemented functionality feedback on what the feature should look like from an end user point of view is welcome!

‌
summary.html:
Note, this is pretty much a work in progress and I’m not too familiar with ogre so I might have missed something or introduced regressions, especially in the ogre1 code.

This PR is to get collada assets with alpha textures to work properly in ignition, both with ogre1 and ogre2.

First of all the asset can be found here, it’s a slightly modified version of the one in this issue (added transparency + transparent properties to the cage object).

Also, in order for this PR to have any effect it is necessary to remove the part of the ColladaLoader in ign-common that overwrites the transparency with a value of 0 and issues a warning whenever a <texture> property is found inside a <transparent> tag, related PR here.

I tested both the asset attached (to verify the change) and a non-textured asset with transparent materials from fuel to make sure there was no regressions. Both seem to render correctly but I might have missed something. Now the details.

Ogre2

  • Setting the blend type to transparent alpha makes the texture render correctly but shadows are wrong. The only way I could get the shadows to work correctly is by setting:

    • AlphaTest: With this setting the shadows that the object projects on the outside are correct (instead of being solid).
    • TwoSidedLighting: Setting this to true was the only way I could get the shadows inside the objects to be correct (the grid projecting a shadow on the blue bag), otherwise there is none.

  • The alpha test threshold is an arbitrary number which changes the projected shadows slightly, I’m open to making it a parameter (although this would probably mean breaking API).

    • If we make the threshold a parameter, where should it come from?

  • I’m open to how we should implement transparency for textures. For now the transparency parameter is still taken and applied to the whole texture (hence even fully opaque alpha textures will be partially transparent, depending on the parameter value). Is this a good behavior or would we want to only use the texture’s alpha channel? I’m afraid that since we need to specify a transparency value greater than 0 to enable alpha blending it will actually be impossible to have a completely opaque texture and this sounds wrong.

OGRE1

  • I removed the manual override of the alpha channel and that fixed the rendering of the cage but to be honest I didn’t spend much time on this so I might have introduced some regression, I’d like to know from who wrote that part in the first place in which cases it was needed.
  • There is still no shadow being projected by the cage on the blue bag. I’ll be looking into fixing this in the coming days.

‌

Again this is very much a work in progress, and since we are adding a previously unimplemented functionality feedback on what the feature should look like from an end user point of view is welcome!

‌

values.title: Add API to check which engines are loaded

summary.html:
Add a couple of functions to check if an engine is already loaded, and to get the list of engines already loaded.

Some use cases:

  • I want to load ogre only if I know ogre2 is not loaded yet, and vice-versa
  • I want to use any (or all) engine that's already loaded without needing to refer to it by name. Then I can do something like:
auto loadedEngines = rendering::loadedEngines();
if (!loadedEngines.empty())
  auto engine = rendering::engine(loadedEngines[0]);

values.description:
I get occasional crashes on `ign-gazebo` like this:

~~~
Invalid parameter at line 374 (@foreach). 'hlms_lights_directional' is not a number nor a variable
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'Ogre::RenderingAPIException'
  what():  OGRE EXCEPTION(3:RenderingAPIException): Fragment Program 536904064PixelShader_ps failed to compile. See compile log above for details. in GLSLShader::compile at /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/ogre-2.1-debbuilder/repo/RenderSystems/GL3Plus/src/GLSL/OgreGLSLShader.cpp (line 308)
~~~

I commented out these lines for now and I haven't been seeing any difference in behaviour regarding directional lights, but I haven't actually looked into what this code is doing. I'll leave this PR here in case someone is interested in investigating.

values.description:
Depends on [ign-common3 pull request 223](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/pull-requests/223/add-function-to-get-nodeanimation/diff)

This PR extends the ogre and ogre2 skeletal animation implementation to load the mesh animations into the rendering engine and let the engine do the animating. The original implementation sets the skeleton bone pose manual which can be slow.

I’ve updated the `actor_animation` example to demonstrate differences between the two skeleton animation methods.

Build and run the `actor_animation` example with the engine you want, e.g.

```
cd examples/actor_animation
mkdir build
cd build
cmake ..
make
./actor_animation ogre2
```

Press `m` to toggle between manual and auto skeleton animation update. The difference in FPS should be small for just one actor in the scene.

Press `t` to add more actors and toggle between manual and auto skeleton animation update to see the increase in performance.

The performance improvement is more evidient in ogre2.x compared to ogre1.x

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/zq9ear/images/1720106814-actor_animation.png)
‌
values.title: Skeleton animation updates

values.description:
depends on [ign-common pull request #227](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/pull-requests/227/add-pbr-material-class/diff)

Ogre2’s PBR material has a high default metalness value \(metalness = 0.8\) which causes objects to appear dark \(when compared to ogre 1.x\). This PR updates the mesh loader to use the default PBR material default values from ign-common \(metalness = 0.5\) when loading meshes and their materials.

To test with the `ogre2_demo`, you can comment out [this line ](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/src/ee3bdc5fbe6ece157ae73fc03af2ce9deade2079/examples/ogre2_demo/Main.cc#lines-111)to let the duck mesh use it’s own default material from ign-common.  Here’s a comparison with and without the changes in this PR \(both with the [line](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/src/ee3bdc5fbe6ece157ae73fc03af2ce9deade2079/examples/ogre2_demo/Main.cc#lines-111) commented out\)

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/zq9ear/images/1696378137-common_pbr_material.png)
‌
values.title: Use default material properties from ign-common PBR material when loading a mesh

summary.html:
depends on ign-common pull request #227

Ogre2’s PBR material has a high default metalness value (metalness = 0.8) which causes objects to appear dark (when compared to ogre 1.x). This PR updates the mesh loader to use the default PBR material default values from ign-common (metalness = 0.5) when loading meshes and their materials.

To test with the ogre2_demo, you can comment out this line to let the duck mesh use it’s own default material from ign-common. Here’s a comparison with and without the changes in this PR (both with the line commented out)

values.description:
Before this PR, only the file name was passed to ogre2 when setting the texture for a mesh, the engine would then look for the first match for that specific filename in all the paths that it saved.  
This resulted in incorrect behavior in case there is multiple models which have textures with the same name, for example both [this asset](https://app.ignitionrobotics.org/openrobotics/fuel/models/SmallTrolley) and [this asset ](https://app.ignitionrobotics.org/openrobotics/fuel/models/HospitalPillow)have a texture called texture.png. If both are loaded, the second one will use the same texture as the first one.

This PR passes the entire file path to the Ogre resource manager instead of only the filename to remove this ambiguity. Its logic is similar to the one in the [Ogre1](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/src/ee3bdc5fbe6ece157ae73fc03af2ce9deade2079/ogre/src/OgreMaterial.cc#lines-502) \(where the bug doesn’t happen\).

It’s not super obvious with the two assets because of the white textures so I edited the pillow’s texture.png to have a big red circle, following the behavior before the PR:

When pillow is the first object to be loaded \(its texture is applied to both objects\):

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/zq9ear/images/845872511-image.png)
And when the trolley is loaded first instead \(trolley texture applied to both objects\):

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/zq9ear/images/2975769559-image.png)
By contrast, this is the behavior after the PR \(every object has the right texture\):

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/zq9ear/images/47541856-image.png)
‌
values.title: Fix texture path in ogre2

summary.html:
Before this PR, only the file name was passed to ogre2 when setting the texture for a mesh, the engine would then look for the first match for that specific filename in all the paths that it saved.
This resulted in incorrect behavior in case there is multiple models which have textures with the same name, for example both this asset and this asset have a texture called texture.png. If both are loaded, the second one will use the same texture as the first one.

This PR passes the entire file path to the Ogre resource manager instead of only the filename to remove this ambiguity. Its logic is similar to the one in the Ogre1 (where the bug doesn’t happen).

It’s not super obvious with the two assets because of the white textures so I edited the pillow’s texture.png to have a big red circle, following the behavior before the PR:

When pillow is the first object to be loaded (its texture is applied to both objects):

And when the trolley is loaded first instead (trolley texture applied to both objects):

By contrast, this is the behavior after the PR (every object has the right texture):

‌

values.reason: The fix increases memory footprint in models with shared textures since they get now duplicated. Needs rethinking on how to handle resource sharing among different models.

values.description:
This PR adds support for transparency based on the alpha channel of the <diffuse> sdf tag in OGRE2.  
OGRE1 \(and Gazebo\) have a slightly different behavior since they use the alpha channel in the <ambient> tag, however the PBS system in OGRE2 doesn’t have ambient colors hence we are switching to using the diffuse channel.

With this PR, the total opacity of an object will be the product of \(1 minus\) the transparency specified in the object’s material \(i.e. in the .dae in Collada or the .mtl in Obj assets\) and the alpha specified in the diffuse channel, this behavior is analogue to Gazebo classic and should make behavior more similar.

Also without this PR there is no way to make transparent primitives purely in SDF, this can now be done.

I merged these changes into the [transparent\_materials\_test](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/commits/2b79cea85e52b5a5ef0548ee0b2ad52518771da3) branch and updated the example to include a box with a partially transparent diffuse / ambient color, behavior \(with OGRE2\), before PR:

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/zq9ear/images/1670342755-image.png)
After:

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/zq9ear/images/4247818063-image.png)
‌
values.title: Added transparency based on diffuse color's alpha channel in OGRE2

summary.raw:
This PR adds support for transparency based on the alpha channel of the <diffuse> sdf tag in OGRE2.  
OGRE1 \(and Gazebo\) have a slightly different behavior since they use the alpha channel in the <ambient> tag, however the PBS system in OGRE2 doesn’t have ambient colors hence we are switching to using the diffuse channel.

With this PR, the total opacity of an object will be the product of \(1 minus\) the transparency specified in the object’s material \(i.e. in the .dae in Collada or the .mtl in Obj assets\) and the alpha specified in the diffuse channel, this behavior is analogue to Gazebo classic and should make behavior more similar.

Also without this PR there is no way to make transparent primitives purely in SDF, this can now be done.

I merged these changes into the [transparent\_materials\_test](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/commits/2b79cea85e52b5a5ef0548ee0b2ad52518771da3) branch and updated the example to include a box with a partially transparent diffuse / ambient color, behavior \(with OGRE2\), before PR:

‌
summary.html:
This PR adds support for transparency based on the alpha channel of the <diffuse> sdf tag in OGRE2.
OGRE1 (and Gazebo) have a slightly different behavior since they use the alpha channel in the <ambient> tag, however the PBS system in OGRE2 doesn’t have ambient colors hence we are switching to using the diffuse channel.

With this PR, the total opacity of an object will be the product of (1 minus) the transparency specified in the object’s material (i.e. in the .dae in Collada or the .mtl in Obj assets) and the alpha specified in the diffuse channel, this behavior is analogue to Gazebo classic and should make behavior more similar.

Also without this PR there is no way to make transparent primitives purely in SDF, this can now be done.

I merged these changes into the transparent_materials_test branch and updated the example to include a box with a partially transparent diffuse / ambient color, behavior (with OGRE2), before PR:

After:

‌

values.description:
Just a few minor fixes to the recently pushed PR that slipped through review.

What triggered the changes is that the compiler in the homebrew CI \(i.e. here  [https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition\_rendering-ci-pr\_any-homebrew-amd64/551/console](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_rendering-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/551/console)\) was returning warnings for the missing override keyword in the overridden functions, the virtual keyword is just for consistency.

summary.html:
Just a few minor fixes to the recently pushed PR that slipped through review.

What triggered the changes is that the compiler in the homebrew CI (i.e. here https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_rendering-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/551/console) was returning warnings for the missing override keyword in the overridden functions, the virtual keyword is just for consistency.

values.description: Ready for review - This PR adds the grid to ogre 2.  It was targeted at Citadel due to the utilization of the `Ogre2DynamicRenderable` class which can't be backported due to API/ABI breaks.
values.title: Ogre2 grid

summary.raw: Ready for review - This PR adds the grid to ogre 2.  It was targeted at Citadel due to the utilization of the `Ogre2DynamicRenderable` class which can't be backported due to API/ABI breaks.

summary.html: backport of pull request #243

values.description:
There were some magic numbers which made the test a bit hard to debug. Changed the shapes positions so that the sphere and box are aligned with the camera and far from each other. Then the test goes through the middle horizontal line from left to right. I chose the numbers so all checked pixels are clearly within one of the 3 regions: box / sphere / empty.

I couldn't reproduce the flaky tests locally even before this, so I'll try it a few times on CI to see how it goes.
values.title: 👩‍🌾 Fix flaky VisualAt test
